This is part 2 of the sequence of blog posts on general theory of processes. For part 1 see here. I will be building upon the content presented there.
Introduction
“Mathematics exists solely for the honour of the human mind.” — Jacobi in a letter to Legendre after the death of Fourier. Fourier had the opinion that the principal aim of mathematics was public utility and explanation of natural phenomena.
We previously discussed Choquet's theory of capacities and its applications in measure theory. The goal of this blog post is to discuss the debut, section and projection theorems in stochastic processes. These theorems form the core of the "general theory of processes", developed primarily by the Strasbourg school of probability under the tutelage of Paul-André Meyer. At the risk of being overly simplistic, general theory of processes is the study of filtrations and stopping times—martingales will be absent in our discussion.
Unlike part 1 where there were no prerequisites other than basic measure theory, this part assumes a good amount of familiarity with stochastic processes, at the level of [1,2]. Without that the material here will feel unmotivated and difficult. On the other hand, the theorems proved here are skipped even in advanced courses in stochastic processes as they aren't the most useful for applications, but rather are necessary to fill in gaps if a rigorous treatment is warranted. Nevertheless the theory presented is extremely profound and beautiful, and reading it will be an honour for the mind, if nothing else.
Setting The Stage
Completion of Measure Spaces and Filtrations
Definition 18: A measure space (E,E,μ)(E, \mathscr{E}, \mu)(E,E,μ)﻿ is called complete if B∈EB \in \mathscr{E}B∈E﻿ and μ(B)=0\mu(B) = 0μ(B)=0﻿ implies that every subset of BBB﻿ is in E.\mathscr E.E.﻿ We call A⊆EA \subseteq EA⊆E﻿ a μ\muμ﻿-negligible or a μ\muμ﻿-null set if there exists B∈EB \in \mathscr EB∈E﻿ such that A⊆BA \subseteq BA⊆B﻿ and μ(B)=0.\mu(B) = 0.μ(B)=0.﻿ A given statement is said to hold μ\muμ﻿-almost everywhere, or simply μ\muμ﻿-a.e., if the set on which it fails is μ\muμ﻿-negligible.
Thus the measure space (E,E,μ)(E, \mathscr{E}, \mu)(E,E,μ)﻿ is complete if and only if every μ\muμ﻿-negligible subset of EEE﻿ belongs to E.\mathscr E.E.﻿
Recall that an outer measure on EEE﻿ is a function μ∗ ⁣:P(E)→[0,∞]\mu^* \colon \mathfrak{P}(E) \to [0, \infty]μ∗:P(E)→[0,∞]﻿ such that
μ∗(∅)=0\mu^*(\varnothing) = 0μ∗(∅)=0﻿,
if A⊆B⊆EA \subseteq B \subseteq EA⊆B⊆E﻿, then μ∗(A)≤μ∗(B)\mu^*(A) \le \mu^*(B)μ∗(A)≤μ∗(B)﻿, and
if {An}n∈N\{A_n\}_{n \in \N}{An​}n∈N​﻿ is a sequence of subsets of EEE﻿, then
μ∗(⋃n∈NAn)≤∑n∈Nμ∗(An).\mu^*\left( \bigcup_{n \in \N} A_n \right) \le \sum_{n \in \N} \mu^*(A_n).μ∗(n∈N⋃​An​)≤n∈N∑​μ∗(An​).
Also recall that a subset B⊆EB \subseteq EB⊆E﻿ is called μ∗\mu^*μ∗﻿-measurable if
μ∗(A)=μ∗(A∩B)+μ∗(A∩Bc),∀  A⊆E.\mu^*(A) = \mu^*(A \cap B) + \mu^*(A \cap B^{\mathsf{c}}), \quad \forall \; A \subseteq E.μ∗(A)=μ∗(A∩B)+μ∗(A∩Bc),∀A⊆E.
It is a simple exercise to show that if B⊆EB \subseteq EB⊆E﻿ is such that either μ∗(B)=0\mu^*(B) = 0μ∗(B)=0﻿ or μ∗(Bc)=0\mu^*(B^\mathsf{c}) = 0μ∗(Bc)=0﻿, then BBB﻿ is μ∗\mu^*μ∗﻿-measurable. Finally, recall that if Mμ∗\mathscr{M}_{\mu^*}Mμ∗​﻿ denotes the collection of all μ∗\mu^*μ∗﻿-measurable subsets of EEE﻿, then Mμ∗\mathscr{M}_{\mu^*}Mμ∗​﻿ is a σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra, and the restriction of μ∗\mu^*μ∗﻿ to Mμ∗\mathscr{M}_{\mu^*}Mμ∗​﻿ is a measure on Mμ∗.\mathscr{M}_{\mu^*}.Mμ∗​.﻿ Therefore, it follows that the measure space (E,Mμ∗,μ∗)(E, \mathscr{M}_{\mu^*}, \mu^*)(E,Mμ∗​,μ∗)﻿ is complete. In particular, the Lebesgue measure on the σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra of Lebesgue subsets of R\RR﻿ is complete. It can be shown that the restriction of Lebesgue measure to the σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra of Borel subsets of R\RR﻿ is not complete. We next discuss a result that allows us to complete any measure space.
Theorem 11: Let (E,E,μ)(E, \mathscr{E}, \mu)(E,E,μ)﻿ be an arbitrary measure space. Define the collection Eμ\mathscr{E}_\muEμ​﻿ to consist of all sets B⊆EB \subseteq EB⊆E﻿ for which there exist B1,B2∈EB_1, B_2 \in \mathscr EB1​,B2​∈E﻿ such that
B1⊆B⊆B2 and μ(B2∖B1)=0.(C1)\begin{align*} \tag{C1} B_1 \subseteq B \subseteq B_2 \text{ and } \mu(B_2 \setminus B_1) = 0. \end{align*}B1​⊆B⊆B2​ and μ(B2​∖B1​)=0.​(C1)
Then Eμ\mathscr{E}_\muEμ​﻿ is a σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra on EEE﻿ that includes E.\mathscr E.E.﻿ Define the function
μ‾ ⁣:Eμ→[0,∞]\overline{\mu} \colon \mathscr E_\mu \to [0, \infty]μ​:Eμ​→[0,∞]
by letting μ‾(B)=μ(B1)\overline{\mu}(B) = \mu(B_1)μ​(B)=μ(B1​)﻿ in the notation above. Then μ‾\overline \muμ​﻿ is well-defined and is a measure on the σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra Eμ\mathscr E_\muEμ​﻿ whose restriction to E\mathscr EE﻿ is simply μ.\mu.μ.﻿ Finally, the measure space (E,Eμ,μ‾)(E, \mathscr E_\mu, \overline \mu)(E,Eμ​,μ​)﻿ is complete, and is called the completion of (E,E,μ).(E, \mathscr{E}, \mu).(E,E,μ).﻿
Proof:
Let us start by showing that Eμ\mathscr{E}_\muEμ​﻿ is a σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra. That Eμ\mathscr{E}_\muEμ​﻿ includes E\mathscr{E}E﻿ is clear by taking B1=B2=BB_1 = B_2 = BB1​=B2​=B﻿ for any B∈E.B \in \mathscr{E}.B∈E.﻿ This, in particular, means that ∅∈Eμ.\varnothing \in \mathscr{E}_\mu.∅∈Eμ​.﻿ Now let B∈EμB \in \mathscr{E}_\muB∈Eμ​﻿ with B1,B2∈EB_1, B_2 \in \mathscr{E}B1​,B2​∈E﻿ as in the theorem statement. (C1)\text{(C1)}(C1)﻿ implies
B2c⊆Bc⊆B1c and μ(B1c∖B2c)=0,B_2^\mathsf{c} \subseteq B^\mathsf c \subseteq B_1^\mathsf{c} \text{ and } \mu(B_1^\mathsf{c} \setminus B_2^\mathsf{c}) = 0,B2c​⊆Bc⊆B1c​ and μ(B1c​∖B2c​)=0,
showing that Bc∈Eμ.B^\mathsf{c} \in \mathscr{E}_\mu.Bc∈Eμ​.﻿ Finally, suppose that {Bn}n∈N\{B^n\}_{n \in \N}{Bn}n∈N​﻿ is a sequence of sets in Eμ\mathscr{E}_\muEμ​﻿, such that for each n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N﻿, B1n,B2n∈EB^n_1, B^n_2 \in \mathscr{E}B1n​,B2n​∈E﻿ be the sets satisfying (C1).\text{(C1)}.(C1).﻿ Then ⋃n∈NB1n\bigcup_{n \in \N} B^n_1⋃n∈N​B1n​﻿ and ⋃n∈NB2n\bigcup_{n \in \N} B^n_2⋃n∈N​B2n​﻿ both belong to E\mathscr EE﻿, and satisfy
⋃n∈NB1n⊆⋃n∈NBn⊆⋃n∈NB2n, andμ(⋃n∈NB2n∖⋃n∈NB1n)≤μ(⋃n∈N(B2n∖B1n))≤∑n∈Nμ(B2n∖B1n)=0,\begin{gather*} \bigcup_{n \in \N} B^n_1 \subseteq \bigcup_{n \in \N} B^n \subseteq \bigcup_{n \in \N} B^n_2, \text{ and} \\ \mu \left( \bigcup_{n \in \N} B^n_2 \setminus \bigcup_{n \in \N} B^n_1 \right) \le \mu \left( \bigcup_{n \in \N} (B^n_2 \setminus B^n_1) \right) \le \sum_{n \in \N} \mu(B^n_2 \setminus B^n_1) = 0, \end{gather*}n∈N⋃​B1n​⊆n∈N⋃​Bn⊆n∈N⋃​B2n​, andμ(n∈N⋃​B2n​∖n∈N⋃​B1n​)≤μ(n∈N⋃​(B2n​∖B1n​))≤n∈N∑​μ(B2n​∖B1n​)=0,​
showing that ⋃n∈NBn∈Eμ.\bigcup_{n \in \N} B^n \in \mathscr{E}_\mu.⋃n∈N​Bn∈Eμ​.﻿
Next, we show that μ‾\overline \muμ​﻿ is well-defined. Using the notation in the statement of the theorem, it follows immediately that μ(B1)=μ(B2).\mu(B_1) = \mu(B_2).μ(B1​)=μ(B2​).﻿ Furthermore, if A⊆BA \subseteq BA⊆B﻿ such that A∈EA \in \mathscr{E}A∈E﻿, then
μ(A)≤μ(B2)=μ(B1).\mu(A) \le \mu(B_2) = \mu(B_1).μ(A)≤μ(B2​)=μ(B1​).
Hence
μ(B1)=sup⁡{μ(A) : A∈E and A⊆B},\mu(B_1) = \sup \{\mu(A) \,:\, A \in \mathscr{E} \text{ and } A \subseteq B\},μ(B1​)=sup{μ(A):A∈E and A⊆B},
and so the common value of μ(B1)\mu(B_1)μ(B1​)﻿ and μ(B2)\mu(B_2)μ(B2​)﻿ depends only on the set BBB﻿ and not on the choice of B1B_1B1​﻿ and B2.B_2.B2​.﻿
Next, we show that μ‾\overline \muμ​﻿ is a measure on Eμ.\mathscr E_\mu.Eμ​.﻿ μ‾\overline \muμ​﻿ is clearly an extension of μ\muμ﻿ by letting B1=B2=BB_1 = B_2 = BB1​=B2​=B﻿ for any B∈E.B \in \mathscr{E}.B∈E.﻿ This, in particular, implies that μ‾(∅)=0.\overline \mu(\varnothing) = 0.μ​(∅)=0.﻿ Non-negativity of the measure μ\muμ﻿ implies the non-negativity of μ‾.\overline \mu.μ​.﻿ Finally, we check the countable additivity. Let {Bn}n∈N\{B^n\}_{n \in \N}{Bn}n∈N​﻿ be a sequence of disjoint sets in Eμ\mathscr E_\muEμ​﻿, such that for each n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N﻿, B1n,B2n∈EB^n_1, B^n_2 \in \mathscr{E}B1n​,B2n​∈E﻿ be the sets satisfying (C1).\text{(C1)}.(C1).﻿ The disjointness of the sets {Bn}n∈N\{B^n\}_{n \in \N}{Bn}n∈N​﻿ implies the disjointness of the sets {B1n}n∈N\{B^n_1\}_{n \in \N}{B1n​}n∈N​﻿, and so we get
μ‾(⋃n∈NBn)=μ(⋃n∈NB1n)=∑n∈Nμ(B1n)=∑n∈Nμ‾(Bn).\overline{\mu}\left( \bigcup_{n \in \N} B^n \right) = \mu\left( \bigcup_{n \in \N} B^n_1 \right) = \sum_{n \in \N} \mu(B^n_1) = \sum_{n \in \N} \overline\mu(B^n).μ​(n∈N⋃​Bn)=μ(n∈N⋃​B1n​)=n∈N∑​μ(B1n​)=n∈N∑​μ​(Bn).
Lastly, we need to check that the measure space (E,Eμ,μ‾)(E, \mathscr E_\mu, \overline \mu)(E,Eμ​,μ​)﻿ is complete. Suppose B∈EμB \in \mathscr E_\muB∈Eμ​﻿ is such that μ‾(B)=0,\overline\mu(B) = 0,μ​(B)=0,﻿ and suppose A⊆B.A \subseteq B.A⊆B.﻿ We need to show that A∈Eμ.A \in \mathscr E_\mu.A∈Eμ​.﻿ Let B1,B2∈EB_1, B_2 \in \mathscr EB1​,B2​∈E﻿ be sets from (C1)\text{(C1)}(C1)﻿. For A1=∅A_1 = \varnothingA1​=∅﻿ and A2=B2A_2 = B_2A2​=B2​﻿, the conditions (C1)\text{(C1)}(C1)﻿ are satisfied for the set A,A,A,﻿ and we are done. □\square□﻿
If we denote by N\mathscr{N}N﻿ the collection of all μ\muμ﻿-negligible sets for the measure space (E,E,μ)(E, \mathscr{E}, \mu)(E,E,μ)﻿, then it is easy to see that
Eμ={B∪N : B∈E and N∈N},(C2)\mathscr E_\mu = \{B \cup N \,:\, B \in \mathscr E \text{ and } N \in \mathscr N\}, \tag{C2}Eμ​={B∪N:B∈E and N∈N},(C2)
and μ‾(B∪N)=μ(B).\overline \mu (B \cup N) = \mu(B).μ​(B∪N)=μ(B).﻿ From this it follows that if the measure space (E,E,μ)(E, \mathscr{E}, \mu)(E,E,μ)﻿ is complete, then it is its own completion.
A very nice property that holds if we assume that the measure space (E,E,μ)(E, \mathscr{E}, \mu)(E,E,μ)﻿ is complete is that if fff﻿ and ggg﻿ are real-valued functions defined EEE﻿ such that fff﻿ is measurable and and f=gf = gf=g﻿ holds μ\muμ﻿-a.e., then ggg﻿ is also measurable. To see this, let B∈B(R)B \in \mathcal{B}(\R)B∈B(R)﻿ be any Borel set. Then {f∈B}∈E\{f \in B\} \in \mathscr E{f∈B}∈E﻿ and
A:={g∈B}∩{f≠g}⊆{f≠g}∈N⊆EA := \{g \in B\} \cap \{f \neq g\} \subseteq \{f \neq g\} \in \mathscr N \subseteq \mathscr EA:={g∈B}∩{f=g}⊆{f=g}∈N⊆E
by our assumptions. Thus, {f=g}={f≠g}c∈E\{f = g\} = \{f \neq g \}^\mathsf{c} \in \mathscr E{f=g}={f=g}c∈E﻿, and
{g∈B}=({f∈B}∩{f=g})∪A∈E\{g \in B\} = \left(\{f \in B\} \cap \{f = g\}\right) \cup A \in \mathscr E{g∈B}=({f∈B}∩{f=g})∪A∈E
allows us to conclude that ggg﻿ is measurable.
The above property can fail if the measure space is not complete. Similar problems can arise in the study of stochastic processes, and therefore completeness assumptions are made. For this whole blog post, we shall place ourselves on a complete probability space (Ω,F,P)(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mathbb{P})(Ω,F,P)﻿ endowed with a filtration F={Ft}0≤t<∞\mathbb{F} = \{\mathcal{F}_t\} _ {0 \le t < \infty}F={Ft​}0≤t<∞​﻿, i.e., a family of sub-σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebras of F\mathcal{F}F﻿ which is increasing in the sense that
Fs⊆Ft⊆F∞:=σ(⋃u∈[0,∞)Fu),0≤s≤t<∞.\mathcal{F}_s \subseteq \mathcal{F}_t \subseteq \mathcal{F}_\infty := \sigma\left(\bigcup_{u \in [0, \infty)} \mathcal{F}_u\right), \quad 0 \le s \le t < \infty.Fs​⊆Ft​⊆F∞​:=σ⎝⎛​u∈[0,∞)⋃​Fu​⎠⎞​,0≤s≤t<∞.
We sometimes denote this setup conveniently as (Ω,F,F,P)(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mathbb{F}, \mathbb{P})(Ω,F,F,P)﻿ and call it a filtered probability space. We shall assume that this filtration satisfies the usual conditions:
Right-continuity, i.e., Ft=Ft+:=⋂s>tFs\mathcal{F}_t = \mathcal{F}_{t+} := \bigcap_{s > t} \mathcal{F}_sFt​=Ft+​:=⋂s>t​Fs​﻿ for all t∈[0,∞)t \in [0, \infty)t∈[0,∞)﻿, and
F0\mathcal{F}_0F0​﻿ contains all the P\mathbb{P}P﻿-negligible events in F\mathcal{F}F﻿.
The structure of the filtration implies that we can write Ft+\mathcal{F}_{t+}Ft+​﻿ equivalently as ⋂n∈NFt+1/n.\bigcap_{n \in \N} \mathcal{F}_{t + 1/n}.⋂n∈N​Ft+1/n​.﻿
Often we will need to start with the natural filtration
FtX:=σ(Xs;  0≤s≤t),t≥0,(F1)\mathcal{F}_t^X := \sigma(X_s; \;0 \le s \le t), \quad t \ge 0, \tag{F1}FtX​:=σ(Xs​;0≤s≤t),t≥0,(F1)
generated by the process X={Xt}t≥0,X = \{X_t\}_{t \ge 0},X={Xt​}t≥0​,﻿ which is the smallest filtration with respect to which the process XXX﻿ is adapted, i.e., XtX_tXt​﻿ is FtX\mathcal{F}_t^XFtX​﻿-measurable for each t≥0.t \ge 0.t≥0.﻿ And then we will need to augment it to make it satisfy the usual conditions. To that end, we define the minimal augmented filtration generated by XXX﻿ to be the smallest filtration that is right continuous and complete and with respect to which the process XXX﻿ is adapted. This can be constructed in the following three steps:
First, let {FtX}t≥0\left\{\mathcal{F}_t^{X}\right\}_{t \ge 0}{FtX​}t≥0​﻿ be the natural filtration as in (F1).\text{(F1)}.(F1).﻿
Let N\mathscr{N}N﻿ be the collection of all P\mathbb{P}P﻿-negligible sets for the complete probability space (Ω,F,P)(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mathbb{P})(Ω,F,P)﻿ (we can always complete it using Theorem 11 if it isn’t). For each t≥0,t \ge 0,t≥0,﻿ let
(FtX)P={F∪N : F∈FtX and N∈N}(F2)\left(\mathcal{F}^X_t\right)_{\mathbb{P}} = \left\{F \cup N \,:\, F \in \mathcal{F}_t^X \text{ and } N \in \mathscr N\right\} \tag{F2}(FtX​)P​={F∪N:F∈FtX​ and N∈N}(F2)
be the completion of FtX\mathcal{F}_t^XFtX​﻿ just like in (C2).\text{(C2)}.(C2).﻿
Finally, for each t≥0,t \ge 0,t≥0,﻿ let
Ft:=((FtX)P)+=⋂s>t(FsX)P(F3)\mathcal{F}_t := \left( \left(\mathcal{F}^X_t\right)_{\mathbb{P}} \right)_+ = \bigcap_{s > t} \left(\mathcal{F}^X_s\right)_{\mathbb{P}} \tag{F3}Ft​:=((FtX​)P​)+​=s>t⋂​(FsX​)P​(F3)
define the right-continuous filtration. To show right-continuity of {Ft}t≥0,\{\mathcal{F}_t\}_{t \ge 0},{Ft​}t≥0​,﻿ we need to show that
⋂s>t(FsX)P=Ft=Ft+=⋂r>t⋂s>r(FsX)P.\bigcap_{s > t} \left(\mathcal{F}^X_s\right)_{\mathbb{P}} = \mathcal{F}_t = \mathcal{F}_{t+} = \bigcap_{r > t} \bigcap_{s > r} \left(\mathcal{F}^X_s\right)_{\mathbb{P}}.s>t⋂​(FsX​)P​=Ft​=Ft+​=r>t⋂​s>r⋂​(FsX​)P​.
But this is obvious since F∈(FsX)PF \in \left(\mathcal{F}^X_s\right)_{\mathbb{P}}F∈(FsX​)P​﻿ for every s>r>ts > r > ts>r>t﻿ is same as saying F∈(FsX)PF \in \left(\mathcal{F}^X_s\right)_{\mathbb{P}}F∈(FsX​)P​﻿ for every s>t.s > t.s>t.﻿
These steps give a filtration {Ft}t≥0,\{\mathcal{F}_t\}_{t \ge 0},{Ft​}t≥0​,﻿ which is right continuous and complete and with respect to which the process XXX﻿ is adapted. It is clear that it is also the smallest such filtration. Does it matter if we do step 3 before step 2, i.e., is it true that
((FtX)P)+=((FtX)+)P?\left( \left(\mathcal{F}^X_t\right)_{\mathbb{P}} \right)_+ = \left( \left(\mathcal{F}^X_t\right)_{+} \right)_{\mathbb{P}} ?((FtX​)P​)+​=((FtX​)+​)P​?
It would be very disappointing if they weren’t equal. Let us start by showing
((FtX)+)P⊆((FtX)P)+.\left( \left(\mathcal{F}^X_t\right)_{+} \right)_{\mathbb{P}} \subseteq \left( \left(\mathcal{F}^X_t\right)_{\mathbb{P}} \right)_+.((FtX​)+​)P​⊆((FtX​)P​)+​.
From (C2),\text{(C2)},(C2),﻿ if F∈((FtX)+)P,F \in \left( \left(\mathcal{F}^X_t\right)_{+} \right)_{\mathbb{P}},F∈((FtX​)+​)P​,﻿ then F=B∪NF = B \cup NF=B∪N﻿ for some B∈(FtX)+B \in \left(\mathcal{F}^X_t\right)_{+}B∈(FtX​)+​﻿ and N∈N.N \in \mathscr N.N∈N.﻿ Then B∈FsXB \in \mathcal{F}^X_sB∈FsX​﻿ for every s>t,s > t,s>t,﻿ which means that B∪N∈(FsX)P,B \cup N \in \left(\mathcal{F}^X_s\right)_{\mathbb{P}},B∪N∈(FsX​)P​,﻿ showing F∈(FsX)PF \in \left(\mathcal{F}^X_s\right)_{\mathbb{P}}F∈(FsX​)P​﻿ for every s>t.s > t.s>t.﻿
For the other side,
((FtX)P)+⊆((FtX)+)P,\left( \left(\mathcal{F}^X_t\right)_{\mathbb{P}} \right)_+ \subseteq \left( \left(\mathcal{F}^X_t\right)_{+} \right)_{\mathbb{P}},((FtX​)P​)+​⊆((FtX​)+​)P​,
let F∈((FtX)P)+.F \in \left( \left(\mathcal{F}^X_t\right)_{\mathbb{P}} \right)_+.F∈((FtX​)P​)+​.﻿ We need to construct B∈(FtX)+B \in \left(\mathcal{F}^X_t\right)_{+}B∈(FtX​)+​﻿ and N∈NN \in \mathscr NN∈N﻿ such that F=B∪N.F = B \cup N.F=B∪N.﻿ By the definition of right-continuity, F∈(Ft+1/nX)PF \in \left(\mathcal{F}^X_{t + 1/n}\right)_{\mathbb{P}}F∈(Ft+1/nX​)P​﻿ for every n∈N,n \in \N,n∈N,﻿ which means there exist sequences {Bn}n∈N\{B_n\}_{n \in \N}{Bn​}n∈N​﻿ and {Nn}n∈N\{N_n\}_{n \in \N}{Nn​}n∈N​﻿ satisfying Bn∈Ft+1/nX,B_n \in \mathcal{F}^X_{t + 1/n},Bn​∈Ft+1/nX​,﻿ Nn∈N,N_n \in \mathscr N,Nn​∈N,﻿ and F=Bn∪NnF = B_n \cup N_nF=Bn​∪Nn​﻿ for each n∈N.n \in \N.n∈N.﻿ Define
B:=lim inf⁡n→∞Bn={Bn,eventually}=⋃k∈N⋂n≥kBn.B := \liminf_{n \to \infty} B_n = \{B_n, \text{eventually}\} = \bigcup_{k \in \N} \bigcap_{n \ge k} B_n.B:=n→∞liminf​Bn​={Bn​,eventually}=k∈N⋃​n≥k⋂​Bn​.
Then note that ⋂n≥kBn∈Ft+1/kX,\bigcap_{n \ge k} B_n \in \mathcal{F}_{t + 1/k}^X,⋂n≥k​Bn​∈Ft+1/kX​,﻿ which implies that for each m∈N,m \in \N,m∈N,﻿
B=⋃k∈N⋂n≥kBn=⋃k≥m⋂n≥kBn∈Ft+1/mX.B = \bigcup_{k \in \N} \bigcap_{n \ge k} B_n = \bigcup_{k \ge m} \bigcap_{n \ge k} B_n \in \mathcal{F}_{t + 1/m}^X.B=k∈N⋃​n≥k⋂​Bn​=k≥m⋃​n≥k⋂​Bn​∈Ft+1/mX​.
This says that B∈(FtX)+.B \in \left(\mathcal{F}^X_t\right)_{+}.B∈(FtX​)+​.﻿ Define N:=F∖B,N := F \setminus B,N:=F∖B,﻿ and note
F∖B=F∩⋂k∈N⋃n≥kBnc=⋂k∈N⋃n≥k(F∖Bn)=⋂k∈N⋃n≥kNn∈N.F \setminus B = F \cap \bigcap_{k \in \N} \bigcup_{n \ge k} B_n^\mathsf{c} = \bigcap_{k \in \N} \bigcup_{n \ge k} (F \setminus B_n) = \bigcap_{k \in \N} \bigcup_{n \ge k} N_n \in \mathscr{N}.F∖B=F∩k∈N⋂​n≥k⋃​Bnc​=k∈N⋂​n≥k⋃​(F∖Bn​)=k∈N⋂​n≥k⋃​Nn​∈N.
This shows the desired inclusion, and we are done.
Stochastic Processes
For our purposes, a stochastic process is simply a collection of real-valued random variables X={Xt}t≥0X = \{X_t\}_{t \ge 0}X={Xt​}t≥0​﻿ on (Ω,F).(\Omega, \mathcal{F}).(Ω,F).﻿ The sample paths of XXX﻿ are the mapping [0,∞)∋t↦Xt(ω)∈R[0, \infty) \ni t \mapsto X_t( \omega) \in \R[0,∞)∋t↦Xt​(ω)∈R﻿ obtained when fixing ω∈Ω.\omega \in \Omega.ω∈Ω.﻿
We need terminology to talk about when two stochastic processes are the “same”.
Definition 19: Consider two stochastic process XXX﻿ and YYY﻿ defined on the same probability space (Ω,F,P).(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mathbb{P}).(Ω,F,P).﻿ We say
XXX﻿ and YYY﻿ have the same finite-dimensional distributions if, for any integer n≥1n \ge 1n≥1﻿, real numbers 0≤t1<t2<⋯<tn<∞,0 \le t_1 < t_2 < \cdots < t_n < \infty,0≤t1​<t2​<⋯<tn​<∞,﻿ and A∈B(Rn)A \in \mathcal{B}(\R^n)A∈B(Rn)﻿, we have
P{(Xt1,…,Xtn)∈A}=P{(Yt1,…,Ytn)∈A};\mathbb{P}\{(X_{t_1}, \ldots, X_{t_n}) \in A\} = \mathbb{P}\{(Y_{t_1}, \ldots, Y_{t_n}) \in A\};P{(Xt1​​,…,Xtn​​)∈A}=P{(Yt1​​,…,Ytn​​)∈A};
YYY﻿ is a modification or a version of XXX﻿ if, for every t∈[0,∞)t \in [0, \infty)t∈[0,∞)﻿, we have P{Xt=Yt}=1;\mathbb{P}\{X_t = Y_t\} = 1;P{Xt​=Yt​}=1;﻿
XXX﻿ and YYY﻿ are indistinguishable if almost all their sample paths agree, i.e.,
P{Xt=Yt    ∀ t∈[0,∞)}=1.\mathbb{P}\{X_t = Y_t \;\; \forall \, t \in [0, \infty)\} = 1.P{Xt​=Yt​∀t∈[0,∞)}=1.
The set {Xt=Yt    ∀ t∈[0,∞)}\{X_t = Y_t \;\; \forall \, t \in [0, \infty)\}{Xt​=Yt​∀t∈[0,∞)}﻿ is measurable because of our completeness assumption.
We will need to make stronger measurability assumptions for the random variables {Xt}t≥0\{X_t\}_{t \ge 0}{Xt​}t≥0​﻿ than just assuming that each XtX_tXt​﻿ is measurable.
Definition 20: A stochastic process X={Xt}t≥0X = \{X_t\}_{t \ge 0}X={Xt​}t≥0​﻿ is called
adapted, if XtX_tXt​﻿ is Ft\mathcal{F}_tFt​﻿-measurable for every t∈[0,∞)t \in [0, \infty)t∈[0,∞)﻿;
measurable, if the mapping
[0,∞)×Ω∋(t,ω)↦Xt(ω)∈R(M1)[0, \infty) \times \Omega \ni (t,\omega) \mapsto X_t(\omega) \in \R \tag{M1}[0,∞)×Ω∋(t,ω)↦Xt​(ω)∈R(M1)
is B([0,∞))⊗F\mathcal{B}([0, \infty)) \otimes \mathcal{F}B([0,∞))⊗F﻿-measurable, when R\RR﻿ is endowed with its Borel σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra;
progressively measurable, if for every t∈[0,∞)t \in [0, \infty)t∈[0,∞)﻿ the mapping
[0,t]×Ω∋(s,ω)↦Xs(ω)∈R[0,t] \times \Omega \ni (s,\omega) \mapsto X_s(\omega) \in \R[0,t]×Ω∋(s,ω)↦Xs​(ω)∈R
is B([0,t])⊗Ft\mathcal{B}([0,t]) \otimes \mathcal{F}_tB([0,t])⊗Ft​﻿-measurable, when R\RR﻿ is endowed with its Borel σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra.
Recall that every progressively measurable process is both measurable and adapted; and every adapted process with right-continuous or with left-continuous paths, is progressively measurable [1,2]. On the other hand, we have the following result due to Meyer (1966).
Theorem 12: Every measurable and adapted process X={Xt}0≤t<∞X = \{X_t\} _ {0 \le t < \infty}X={Xt​}0≤t<∞​﻿ has a progressively measurable modification Y={Yt}0≤t<∞.Y = \{Y_t\} _ {0 \le t < \infty}.Y={Yt​}0≤t<∞​.﻿
Proof:
Consider the space L0\mathbb{L}^0L0﻿ of equivalence classes of measurable functions f:Ω→Rf : \Omega \to \Rf:Ω→R﻿, and endow it with the topology of convergence in probability, for example with the pseudo-metrics ρ(f,g)=E(1∧∣f−g∣)\rho(f, g) = \mathbb E (1 \wedge |f-g|)ρ(f,g)=E(1∧∣f−g∣)﻿ or ρ(f,g)=E(∣f−g∣1+∣f−g∣).\rho(f,g) = \mathbb E \left( \frac{|f-g|}{1 + |f-g|} \right).ρ(f,g)=E(1+∣f−g∣∣f−g∣​).﻿ Recall that if a sequence {fn}n∈N⊆L0\{f_n\} _ {n \in \N} \subseteq \mathbb{L}^0{fn​}n∈N​⊆L0﻿ satisfies ∑n∈Nρ(fn,fn+1)<∞,\sum _ {n \in \N} \rho(f _ n, f _ {n+1}) < \infty,∑n∈N​ρ(fn​,fn+1​)<∞,﻿ then it converges in probability "fast", thus also almost surely.
Every process Y={Y(t)}0≤t<∞Y = \{Y(t)\} _ {0 \le t < \infty}Y={Y(t)}0≤t<∞​﻿ can be thought of as a mapping from [0,∞)[0, \infty)[0,∞)﻿ into L0\mathbb{L}^0L0﻿, which associates to each element in [0,∞)[0, \infty)[0,∞)﻿ the equivalence class Yt\mathcal{Y} _ tYt​﻿ of Y(t).Y(t).Y(t).﻿ Consider now the collection H\mathscr{H}H﻿ of processes YYY﻿ such that the mapping [0,∞)∋t↦Yt∈L0[0, \infty) \ni t \mapsto \mathcal{Y}_t \in \mathbb{L}^0[0,∞)∋t↦Yt​∈L0﻿ satisfies
it takes values in a separable subspace of L0\mathbb{L}^0L0﻿;
under it, the inverse image of every open ball of L0\mathbb{L}^0L0﻿ is a Borel subset of [0,∞)[0, \infty)[0,∞)﻿; and
it is the uniform limit of a sequence of simple measurable functions with values in the space L0.\mathbb{L}^0.L0.﻿
Then note that property 3 implies the other two, and that conversely, properties 1 and 2 together imply property 3, because a real-valued function is measurable if and only if it is the increasing limit of a sequence of simple measurable functions.
Next, note that H\mathscr{H}H﻿ is a real vector space on account of property 3, and is closed under sequential pointwise convergence on account of properties 1 and 2. It is easy to see that H\mathscr{H}H﻿ contains all processes of the form Y(t,ω)=K(t)ξ(ω)Y(t,\omega) = K(t) \xi(\omega)Y(t,ω)=K(t)ξ(ω)﻿, where KKK﻿ is the indicator of an interval in [0,∞)[0, \infty)[0,∞)﻿ and ξ:Ω→R\xi : \Omega \to \Rξ:Ω→R﻿ is a bounded measurable function. Thus, monotone class theorem implies H\mathscr{H}H﻿ contains all bounded measurable processes. Now using a standard slicing argument it is easily seen that every measurable process YYY﻿ has properties 1, 2 and 3.
Consider now a measurable and adapted process X={Xt}t≥0.X = \{X_t\} _ {t \ge 0}.X={Xt​}t≥0​.﻿ For each n∈N{n \in \N}n∈N﻿, there exists a process X(n)={Xt(n)}t≥0X^{(n)} = \{X^{(n)}_t\} _ {t \ge 0}X(n)={Xt(n)​}t≥0​﻿ which is simple and measurable (in the sense that there exists a partition {Ak(n)}k∈N\left\{A^{(n)} _ k\right\} _ {k \in \N}{Ak(n)​}k∈N​﻿ of [0,∞)[0, \infty)[0,∞)﻿ into Borel sets, and a sequence of random variable {Hk(n)}k∈N\left\{H^{(n)} _ k\right\} _ {k \in \N}{Hk(n)​}k∈N​﻿, such that Xt(n)=Hk(n)X^{(n)}_t = H^{(n)} _ kXt(n)​=Hk(n)​﻿ for t∈Ak(n)t \in A^{(n)} _ kt∈Ak(n)​﻿), and satisfies

Definition 21: The σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra of progressively measurable sets, denoted by P⋆\mathscr{P} _ \starP⋆​﻿, is the smallest σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra on the product space [0,∞)×Ω[0, \infty) \times \Omega[0,∞)×Ω﻿, with respect to which the mappings as in (M1)\text{(M1)}(M1)﻿ are measurable for all progressively measurable processes X.X.X.﻿

Stopping Times
Definition 22: A random variable T:Ω→[0,∞]T : \Omega \to [0, \infty]T:Ω→[0,∞]﻿ is called a stopping time if {T≤t}∈Ft\{T \le t\} \in \mathcal{F}_t{T≤t}∈Ft​﻿ for all t∈[0,∞).t \in [0, \infty).t∈[0,∞).﻿
Because the filtration F\mathbb{F}F﻿ is right-continuous this is equivalent to {T<t}∈Ft\{T < t\} \in \mathcal{F}_t{T<t}∈Ft​﻿ for all t∈[0,∞)t \in [0, \infty)t∈[0,∞)﻿ as can be seen by writing
{T≤t}=⋂q∈Q,t<q<s{T<q}∈Fs.\{T \le t\} = \bigcap_{\substack{q \in \mathbb{Q}, \, t < q < s}} \{T < q\} \in \mathcal{F}_s.{T≤t}=q∈Q,t<q<s​⋂​{T<q}∈Fs​.
It is easily checked that if TTT﻿ and SSS﻿ are stopping times, then so are
T∧S, T∨S and T+S.T \wedge S,\, T \vee S \text{ and } T+S.T∧S,T∨S and T+S.
Likewise, if {Tn}n∈N\{T_n\}_{n \in \N}{Tn​}n∈N​﻿ is a sequence of stopping times, then
sup⁡nTn, inf⁡nTn, lim sup⁡n→∞Tn and lim inf⁡n→∞Tn\sup_n T_n,\, \inf_n T_n,\, \limsup_{n \to \infty} T_n \text{ and } \liminf_{n \to \infty} T_nnsup​Tn​,ninf​Tn​,n→∞limsup​Tn​ and n→∞liminf​Tn​
are also stopping times. Stopping times go like “hand-in-glove” with progressive measurability. Suppose X={Xt}t≥0X = \{X_t\}_{t \ge 0}X={Xt​}t≥0​﻿ is F\mathbb{F}F﻿-progressively measurable and TTT﻿ an F\mathbb{F}F﻿-stopping . Then, the stopped process
{XT∧t}t≥0\left\{X_{T \wedge t}\right\}_{t \ge 0}{XT∧t​}t≥0​
is F\mathbb{F}F﻿-progressively measurable.
Definition 23: For a stopping time TTT﻿, we define
σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra of events prior to it by
F(T):={A∈F : A∩{T≤t}∈F(t),∀  t∈[0,∞)};\mathcal{F}(T) := \{A \in \mathcal{F}\,:\, A \cap \{T \le t\} \in \mathcal{F}(t), \quad \forall \; t \in [0, \infty)\};F(T):={A∈F:A∩{T≤t}∈F(t),∀t∈[0,∞)};
σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra of events strictly prior to it by
F(T−):=σ(F(0)∪{A∩{T>t} : t∈[0,∞), A∈F(t)}).\mathcal{F}(T-) := \sigma(\mathcal{F}(0) \cup \left\{A \cap \{T > t\} \,:\, t \in [0, \infty), \, A \in \mathcal{F}(t)\right\}).F(T−):=σ(F(0)∪{A∩{T>t}:t∈[0,∞),A∈F(t)}).
The following intuitive properties are useful and their proofs can be found in any standard textbook [1,2].
Lemma 6: Let TTT﻿ and SSS﻿ be any two stopping times. Then
F(T−)⊆F(T)\mathcal{F}(T-) \subseteq \mathcal{F}(T)F(T−)⊆F(T)﻿;

If the stopping times satisfy T≤ST \le ST≤S﻿, then F(T)⊆F(S)\mathcal{F}(T) \subseteq \mathcal{F}(S)F(T)⊆F(S)﻿ and F(T−)⊆F(S−)\mathcal{F}(T-) \subseteq \mathcal{F}(S-)F(T−)⊆F(S−)﻿;

If {Tn}n∈N\{T_n\} _ {n \in \N}{Tn​}n∈N​﻿ is an increasing sequence of stopping times and T=lim⁡n∈N↑TnT = \lim _ {n \in \N} \uparrow T_nT=limn∈N​↑Tn​﻿, then
F(T−)=σ(⋃n∈NF(Tn−));as well as  F(T−)=σ(⋃n∈NF(Tn))\mathcal{F}(T-) = \sigma\left(\bigcup_{n \in \N} \mathcal{F}(T_n-)\right); \quad \text{as well as  } \mathcal{F}(T-) = \sigma\left(\bigcup_{n \in \N} \mathcal{F}(T_n)\right)F(T−)=σ(n∈N⋃​F(Tn​−));as well as  F(T−)=σ(n∈N⋃​F(Tn​))

Predictable Stopping Times
A very important result states that every stopping time is the decreasing limit of a sequence of discrete stopping time. More concretely, if TTT﻿ is a stopping time, and we define
Tn(ω)={k2−non {k−12n≤T<k2n}T(ω)on {T=∞},T_n(\omega) = \begin{cases} k 2^{-n} &\text{on } \left\{\frac{k-1}{2^n} \le T < \frac{k}{2^n}\right\} \\ T(\omega) &\text{on } \{T = \infty\}, \end{cases}Tn​(ω)={k2−nT(ω)​on {2nk−1​≤T<2nk​}on {T=∞},​
for n,k∈N,n,k \in \N,n,k∈N,﻿ then each TnT_nTn​﻿ is a discrete stopping time and we have Tn↓T.T_n \downarrow T.Tn​↓T.﻿ When can we approximate a stopping with an increasing sequence of stopping times? Of course, being able to do that means that our stopping time is a very special one. We give a name to such stopping times.
Definition 24: A stopping time TTT﻿ is called predictable, if there exists an increasing ("announcing") sequence {Tn}n∈N\{T_n\} _ {n \in \N}{Tn​}n∈N​﻿ of stopping times with T=lim⁡n∈N↑TnT = \lim _ {n \in \N} \uparrow T_nT=limn∈N​↑Tn​﻿, and Tn<TT_n < TTn​<T﻿ holds on the set {T>0}\{T > 0\}{T>0}﻿ for all n∈N.{n \in \N}.n∈N.﻿
Note {T≤t}=⋂n∈N{Tn≤t}∈F(t)\{T \le t\} = \bigcap_{n \in \N} \{T_n \le t\} \in \mathcal{F}(t){T≤t}=⋂n∈N​{Tn​≤t}∈F(t)﻿ and therefore if in the definition above we had not required TTT﻿ to be a stopping time, it would still be a stopping time. A canonical example of a predictable stopping time is the first time Brownian motion WWW﻿ hits or exceeds a certain level b.b.b.﻿ It is announced by the sequence of first times WWW﻿ hits or exceeds the levels b−1/nb - 1/nb−1/n﻿, for n∈N.{n \in \N}.n∈N.﻿ In fact, we have (from [3])
Theorem 13: Let XXX﻿ be a continuous adapted process and bbb﻿ be a real number. Then
T=inf⁡{t∈[0,∞) : X(t)≥b}T = \inf \{t \in [0, \infty)\,:\,X(t) \ge b\}T=inf{t∈[0,∞):X(t)≥b}
is a predictable stopping time.
Proof:
Let
Tn=inf⁡{t∈[0,∞) : X(t)≥b−1/n},T_n = \inf \{t \in [0, \infty)\,:\,X(t) \ge b - 1/n\},Tn​=inf{t∈[0,∞):X(t)≥b−1/n},
which, by the Debut Theorem below (Theorem 14) is a stopping time. This gives an increasing sequence {Tn}n∈N\{T_n\} _ {n \in \N}{Tn​}n∈N​﻿ of stopping times bounded above by T.T.T.﻿ Also, X(Tn)≥b−1/nX(T _ n) \ge b - 1/nX(Tn​)≥b−1/n﻿ whenever Tn<∞T _ n < \inftyTn​<∞﻿ and, by left-continuity, setting τ=lim⁡nTn\tau = \lim _ n T _ nτ=limn​Tn​﻿ gives X(τ)≥bX(\tau) \ge bX(τ)≥b﻿ whenever τ<∞.\tau < \infty.τ<∞.﻿ So T≥τT \ge \tauT≥τ﻿, showing that T=lim⁡n∈N↑Tn.T = \lim _ {n \in \N} \uparrow T_n.T=limn∈N​↑Tn​.﻿ If 0<Tn≤T<∞0 < T _ n \le T < \infty0<Tn​≤T<∞﻿ then, by continuity, X(Tn)=b−1/n<b=X(T).X(T_n) = b - 1/n < b = X(T).X(Tn​)=b−1/n<b=X(T).﻿ So, Tn<TT_n < TTn​<T﻿ on the set {0<T<∞}\{0 < T < \infty\}{0<T<∞}﻿ and the sequence {Tn∧n}n∈N\{T_n \wedge n\} _ {n \in \N}{Tn​∧n}n∈N​﻿ announces T.T.T.﻿ □\square□﻿
Of course, in the above proof we cheated by assuming the Debut Theorem for stopping times, proving which is our next agenda. In the same flavor as Lemma-6 we have
Lemma 7: If TTT﻿ is a predictable stopping time and SSS﻿ an arbitrary stopping time, then
A∩{T≤S}∈F(S−)A \cap \{T \le S\} \in \mathcal{F}(S-)A∩{T≤S}∈F(S−)﻿ for all A∈F(T−)A \in \mathcal{F}(T-)A∈F(T−)﻿;

In particular, both the events {T≤S}\{T \le S\}{T≤S}﻿ and {T=S}\{T = S\}{T=S}﻿ belong to F(S−).\mathcal{F}(S-).F(S−).﻿
Debut of a Progressive Set
Definition 25: For any measurable mapping Z:Ω→[0,∞]Z : \Omega \to [0, \infty]Z:Ω→[0,∞]﻿ and any A∈FA \in \mathcal{F}A∈F﻿, we define the restriction of ZZZ﻿ on AAA﻿ as
ZA:=Z1A+∞1Ac.Z_A := Z \mathbf{1}_{A} + \infty \mathbf{1}_{A^\mathsf{c}}.ZA​:=Z1A​+∞1Ac​.

If TTT﻿ is a stopping time and A∈F(T)A \in \mathcal{F}(T)A∈F(T)﻿, then since {TA≤t}={T≤t}∩A∈F(t)\{T_A \le t\} = \{T \le t\} \cap A \in \mathcal{F}(t){TA​≤t}={T≤t}∩A∈F(t)﻿ for all t∈[0,∞)t \in [0, \infty)t∈[0,∞)﻿, TAT_ATA​﻿ is also a stopping time.
Theorem 14 [Debut of a Progressive Set]: Under the usual conditions, if AAA﻿ is a progressively measurable set, i.e., A∈P⋆A \in \mathscr{P}_\starA∈P⋆​﻿, then the debut DAD_ADA​﻿ is a stopping time.
Proof:
Since A∈P⋆⊆B([0,∞))⊗FA \in \mathscr{P}_\star \subseteq \mathcal{B}([0, \infty)) \otimes \mathcal{F}A∈P⋆​⊆B([0,∞))⊗F﻿, Measurable Debut theorem (Theorem 9) implies DAD_ADA​﻿ is a random variable.
Just like in the proof of Theorem 9, for any real number t>0t > 0t>0﻿, the set {DA<t}\{D_A < t\}{DA​<t}﻿ is the projection onto Ω\OmegaΩ﻿ of the set At:=A∩([0,t)×Ω).A_t := A \cap ([0, t) \times \Omega).At​:=A∩([0,t)×Ω).﻿ Recall that A∈P⋆A \in \mathscr{P}_\starA∈P⋆​﻿ implies At∈B([0,t])⊗F(t).A_t \in \mathcal{B}([0,t]) \otimes \mathcal{F}(t).At​∈B([0,t])⊗F(t).﻿ Therefore, Measurable Projection theorem (Theorem 7) implies {DA<t}=π(At)∈F(t).\{D_A < t\} = \pi(A_t) \in \mathcal{F}(t).{DA​<t}=π(At​)∈F(t).﻿ Right continuity of the filtration now implies DAD_ADA​﻿ is an F\mathbb{F}F﻿-stopping time. □\square□﻿
The following important theorem now becomes an easy corollary.
Theorem 15 [First Hitting Times]: In the context above, if XXX﻿ is a progressively measurable process and Γ∈B(R)\Gamma \in \mathcal{B}(\R)Γ∈B(R)﻿, the first hitting time
HΓ:=inf⁡{t∈[0,∞) : X(t)∈Γ}H_\Gamma := \inf \{t \in [0, \infty)\,:\,X(t) \in \Gamma\}HΓ​:=inf{t∈[0,∞):X(t)∈Γ}
is a stopping time.
Proof:
Since XXX﻿ is a progressively measurable process, the set A={(t,ω)∈[0,∞)×Ω : X(t,ω)∈Γ}A = \{(t,\omega) \in [0, \infty) \times \Omega\,:\,X(t, \omega) \in \Gamma\}A={(t,ω)∈[0,∞)×Ω:X(t,ω)∈Γ}﻿ is a progressively measurable set. Theorem 14 then implies the debut DAD_ADA​﻿ is a stopping time, but it is easy to see DA=HΓ.D_A = H_\Gamma.DA​=HΓ​.﻿ □\square□﻿
Optional and Predictable Processes
Definition 26: The predictable σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra, denoted by P\mathscr{P}P﻿, is the smallest σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra on [0,∞)×Ω[0, \infty) \times \Omega[0,∞)×Ω﻿ with respect to which left-continuous F\mathbb{F}F﻿-adapted processes are measurable. A stochastic process is said to predictable if it is P\mathscr{P}P﻿-measurable.
Definition 27: The optional σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra, denoted by O\mathscr{O}O﻿, is the smallest σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra on [0,∞)×Ω[0, \infty) \times \Omega[0,∞)×Ω﻿ with respect to which right-continuous F\mathbb{F}F﻿-adapted processes are measurable. A stochastic process is said to optional if it is O\mathscr{O}O﻿-measurable.
Since all right-continuous or left-continuous adapted processes are progressively measurable, all optional or predictable processes are adapted. We need the concept of stochastic intervals to ease some notation and see some examples of optional and predictable sets.
Definition 28: If U,V:Ω→[0,∞]U,V : \Omega \to [0, \infty]U,V:Ω→[0,∞]﻿ are two random variables, and U≤VU \le VU≤V﻿, then define the stochastic intervals as
⟦U,V⟧:={(t,ω)∈[0,∞)×Ω : U(ω)≤t≤V(ω)}⟦U,V⟦:={(t,ω)∈[0,∞)×Ω : U(ω)≤t<V(ω)}⟧U,V⟧:={(t,ω)∈[0,∞)×Ω : U(ω)<t≤V(ω)}⟧U,V⟦:={(t,ω)∈[0,∞)×Ω : U(ω)<t<V(ω)}.\begin{align*} \llbracket U,V \rrbracket &:= \{(t,\omega) \in [0, \infty) \times \Omega\,:\,U(\omega) \le t \le V(\omega)\} \\ \llbracket U,V \llbracket &:= \{(t,\omega) \in [0, \infty) \times \Omega\,:\,U(\omega) \le t < V(\omega)\} \\ \rrbracket U,V \rrbracket &:= \{(t,\omega) \in [0, \infty) \times \Omega\,:\,U(\omega) < t \le V(\omega)\} \\ \rrbracket U,V \llbracket &:= \{(t,\omega) \in [0, \infty) \times \Omega\,:\,U(\omega) < t < V(\omega)\}. \end{align*}[[U,V]][[U,V[[]]U,V]]]]U,V[[​:={(t,ω)∈[0,∞)×Ω:U(ω)≤t≤V(ω)}:={(t,ω)∈[0,∞)×Ω:U(ω)≤t<V(ω)}:={(t,ω)∈[0,∞)×Ω:U(ω)<t≤V(ω)}:={(t,ω)∈[0,∞)×Ω:U(ω)<t<V(ω)}.​

It is a simple exercise to show

Properties of Debuts
Recall the setting of section "Measurable Section" from part 1. We showed there that if A∈B([0,∞))⊗F,A \in \mathcal{B}([0, \infty)) \otimes \mathcal{F},A∈B([0,∞))⊗F,﻿ then we can define a measurable mapping T:Ω→[0,∞]T : \Omega \to [0, \infty]T:Ω→[0,∞]﻿ such that for all ω∈π(A)\omega \in \pi(A)ω∈π(A)﻿ we have (T(ω),ω)∈A(T(\omega), \omega) \in A(T(ω),ω)∈A﻿, or stated more succinctly, ⟦T⟧⊆A.\llbracket T \rrbracket \subseteq A.[[T]]⊆A.﻿ Now, what if we want something stronger, say, TTT﻿ should be a stopping time? As we will see, we will have to make stronger assumptions on the set AAA﻿ and even then if we want TTT﻿ to be a stopping time we will have to let go of the nice property that {T<∞}=π(A).\{T < \infty\}= \pi(A).{T<∞}=π(A).﻿
But first, we need to prove a certain property of debuts which we will need in proving the aforementioned section theorem, and that's the goal of this section.
It isn't difficult to see that P\mathscr{P}P﻿ coincides with the mosaic generated by the paving on [0,∞)×Ω[0, \infty) \times \Omega[0,∞)×Ω﻿ that consists of finite unions of stochastic intervals of the form ⟦S,T⟧\llbracket S,T \rrbracket[[S,T]]﻿, where S,T∈S(P).S,T \in \mathfrak{S}^{(\mathscr{P})}.S,T∈S(P).﻿ Generalizing this, let us consider a collection A\mathfrak{A}A﻿ (A\mathfrak{A}A﻿ is A in fraktur font) of stopping times that contains 000﻿ and ∞\infty∞﻿, and which is closed under a.s. equality and under finitely many lattice operations (∧\wedge∧﻿ and ∨\vee∨﻿). We denote by J:={⟦U,V⟦ : S,T∈A}\mathcal{J} := \{\llbracket U,V \llbracket\,:\,S,T \in \mathfrak{A}\}J:={[[U,V[[:S,T∈A}﻿, and by T\mathcal{T}T﻿ the collection of finite unions of elements of J.\mathcal{J}.J.﻿
Simple observations like ⟦S,T⟦c=⟦0,S⟦ ∪ ⟦T,∞⟦\llbracket S,T \llbracket^\mathsf{c} = \llbracket 0, S \llbracket \, \cup \, \llbracket T, \infty \llbracket[[S,T[[c=[[0,S[[∪[[T,∞[[﻿ or ⟦S,T⟦ ∩ ⟦U,V⟦=⟦S∨U,(S∨U)∨(T∧V)⟦\llbracket S,T \llbracket \, \cap \, \llbracket U,V \llbracket = \llbracket S \vee U, (S \vee U) \vee (T \wedge V) \llbracket[[S,T[[∩[[U,V[[=[[S∨U,(S∨U)∨(T∧V)[[﻿ can be used to show that J\mathcal{J}J﻿ is a paving on [0,∞)×Ω[0, \infty) \times \Omega[0,∞)×Ω﻿ and T\mathcal{T}T﻿ is an algebra on [0,∞)×Ω.[0, \infty) \times \Omega.[0,∞)×Ω.﻿
For more structure, let us impose the following properties on the collection A\mathfrak{A}A﻿:
For any pair S,T∈AS,T \in \mathfrak{A}S,T∈A﻿, the stopping time S{S<T}S _ {\{S < T\}}S{S<T}​﻿ (recall the notation of Definition 25 and the observation right after it) belongs to A\mathfrak{A}A﻿;
For any increasing sequence {Sn}n∈N⊆A\{S_n\} _ {n \in \N} \subseteq \mathfrak{A}{Sn​}n∈N​⊆A﻿, the limit lim⁡n∈N↑Sn\lim _ {n \in \N} \uparrow S_nlimn∈N​↑Sn​﻿ belongs to A.\mathfrak{A}.A.﻿
Property 1 ensures that the debut of an element of T\mathcal{T}T﻿ belongs to A.\mathfrak{A}.A.﻿ This is because S{S<T}=D⟦S,T⟦S_{\{S < T\}} = D_{\llbracket S,T \llbracket}S{S<T}​=D[[S,T[[​﻿ and because the debut of union of a finite collection of elements from J\mathcal{J}J﻿ is equal to to the minimum of the debuts of those elements.
Property 2 ensures that the debut of an element of Tδ\mathcal{T} _ \deltaTδ​﻿ (which recall equals {⋃n∈NAn : An∈T for all n∈N}\left\{\bigcup _ {n \in \N} A_n \,:\, A_n \in \mathcal{T} \text{ for all } {n \in \N}\right\}{⋃n∈N​An​:An​∈T for all n∈N}﻿) belongs to to A.\mathfrak{A}.A.﻿ This is the main result of this section, and is proved below as Theorem 16.
Coming out of the abstraction for a bit, we note that the collection S\mathfrak{S}S﻿ of all stopping times satisfies all the conditions imposed above on A.\mathfrak{A}.A.﻿ Similarly for the collection S(P)\mathfrak{S}^{(\mathscr{P})}S(P)﻿ of all predictable stopping times. The first claim is trivial to see. To show the second claim, we first prove the following lemma.
Lemma 10: For any stopping time TTT﻿ and set A∈F(T)A \in \mathcal{F}(T)A∈F(T)﻿, the random variable TAT_ATA​﻿ is a stopping time as we saw above. Coming back to the second claim above, if S,T∈S(P)S,T \in \mathfrak{S}^{(\mathscr{P})}S,T∈S(P)﻿, then by Lemma 7, {S<T}∈F(S−)\{S < T\} \in \mathcal{F}(S-){S<T}∈F(S−)﻿, and thus by Lemma 10, S{S<T}∈S(P).S _ {\{S < T\}} \in \mathfrak{S}^{(\mathscr{P})}.S{S<T}​∈S(P).﻿ The rest of the conditions are trivial to check.
Theorem 16: Suppose A\mathfrak{A}A﻿ is a collection of stopping times with the properties postulated above, and let B∈Tδ.B \in \mathcal{T}_\delta.B∈Tδ​.﻿ Then the debut DBD_BDB​﻿ of this set is a stopping time in A\mathfrak{A}A﻿, and its graph ⟦DB⟧⊆B.\llbracket D_B\rrbracket \subseteq B.[[DB​]]⊆B.﻿
Proof:
We first show that ⟦DB⟧⊆B.\llbracket D_B\rrbracket \subseteq B.[[DB​]]⊆B.﻿ If (s,ω)∈⟦DB⟧(s, \omega) \in\llbracket D_B\rrbracket(s,ω)∈[[DB​]]﻿, then DB(ω)=sD_B(\omega) = sDB​(ω)=s﻿ which is same as saying
s=inf⁡{t∈[0,∞) : (t,ω)∈B}.s = \inf \{t \in [0, \infty)\,:\,(t,\omega) \in B\}.s=inf{t∈[0,∞):(t,ω)∈B}.
But we constructed our collection Tδ\mathcal{T}_\deltaTδ​﻿ using stochastic intervals of the form ⟦S,T⟦\llbracket S,T \llbracket[[S,T[[﻿, and thus

is closed, implying (s,ω)∈B.(s, \omega) \in B.(s,ω)∈B.﻿
To show that DB∈AD_B \in \mathfrak{A}DB​∈A﻿, consider the collection

The next result is Proposition 1.2.26 from Karatzas and Shreve [1], and is left unproven there.
Theorem 17: Under the usual conditions, let XXX﻿ be an adapted process with paths that are RCLL. The jumps of XXX﻿ are exhausted by a sequence of stopping times {Tn}n∈N\{T_n\}_{n \in \N}{Tn​}n∈N​﻿,

where the notation #B\#B#B﻿ denotes cardinaility of a set B.B.B.﻿
We claim that all elements of the sequence {DAnp}p,n∈N\left\{D_{A_n}^p\right\}_{p,n \in \N}{DAn​p​}p,n∈N​﻿ are stopping times. This is sufficient to prove our desired result.
Start by noting that the process XXX﻿ is progressively measurable and the process (t,ω)↦X(t−,ω)(t, \omega) \mapsto X(t-, \omega)(t,ω)↦X(t−,ω)﻿ is left-continuous and adapted, and thus predictable. by Lemma 8. □\square□﻿
Section Theorems
We are now ready to come back to proving section theorems. We start by proving a general section theorem.
Theorem 18 [General Section Theorem]: In the context of Theorem 16, let H\mathscr{H}H﻿ be the σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra generated by the algebra T.\mathcal{T}.T.﻿ For every set A∈HA \in \mathscr{H}A∈H﻿ and ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0﻿, there exists a stopping time Tε∈AT_\varepsilon \in \mathfrak{A}Tε​∈A﻿ with

∫[0,∞)×Ωf(t,ω) ν(dt,dω)=∫{Z<∞}f(Z(ω),ω) P(dω)\int_{[0, \infty) \times \Omega} f(t, \omega) \, \nu(\mathrm{d} t, \mathrm{d} \omega) = \int_{\{Z < \infty\}} f(Z(\omega), \omega) \, \mathbb{P}(\mathrm{d} \omega)∫[0,∞)×Ω​f(t,ω)ν(dt,dω)=∫{Z<∞}​f(Z(ω),ω)P(dω)

Choquet’s capacitability theorem (Theorem 6 in part 1) applied to the paving T\mathcal{T}T﻿ and to the capacity
ν∗(C):=inf⁡B∈H, C⊆Bν(B),C⊆[0,∞)×Ω,\nu^*(C) := \inf _ {B \in \mathscr{H},\, C \subseteq B} \nu(B), \quad C \subseteq [0, \infty) \times \Omega,ν∗(C):=B∈H,C⊆Binf​ν(B),C⊆[0,∞)×Ω,

Theorem 19 [Optional and Predictable Sections]: Let AAA﻿ be an optional (respectively, predictable) subset of the product space [0,∞)×Ω.[0, \infty) \times \Omega.[0,∞)×Ω.﻿ For every ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0﻿, there exists a stopping time (respectively, a predictable stopping time) TεT_\varepsilonTε​﻿ with
⟦Tε⟧⊆A and P[π(A)]≤P(Tε<∞)+ε.(S1)\llbracket T_\varepsilon \rrbracket \subseteq A \text{ and } \mathbb{P}\left[\pi(A)\right] \le \mathbb{P}(T_\varepsilon < \infty) + \varepsilon \tag{S1}.[[Tε​]]⊆A and P[π(A)]≤P(Tε​<∞)+ε.(S1)
Proof:
Both statements follow from the General Section Theorem (Theorem 17) in conjunction with the observations before Lemma 10, by taking A\mathfrak{A}A﻿ to be either S\mathfrak{S}S﻿ or S(P).\mathfrak{S}^{(\mathscr{P})}.S(P).﻿ □\square□﻿
As mentioned in the beginning of the section "Properties of Debuts", we didn't get the nice equality
⟦T⟧⊆A and {T<∞}=π(A)(S2)\llbracket T \rrbracket \subseteq A \text{ and } \{T < \infty\} = \pi(A) \tag{S2}[[T]]⊆A and {T<∞}=π(A)(S2)
as we got in Measurable Section theorem, but instead obtained an approximation (S1).\text{(S1)}.(S1).﻿ The condition ⟦Tε⟧⊆A\llbracket T_\varepsilon \rrbracket \subseteq A[[Tε​]]⊆A﻿ makes sure that {Tε<∞}⊆π(A)\{T_\varepsilon < \infty\} \subseteq \pi(A){Tε​<∞}⊆π(A)﻿, and the P[π(A)]≤P(Tε<∞)+ε\mathbb{P}\left[\pi(A)\right] \le \mathbb{P}(T_\varepsilon < \infty) + \varepsilonP[π(A)]≤P(Tε​<∞)+ε﻿ part ensures that the measure of the difference P[π(A)∖{Tε<∞}]\mathbb{P}\left[ \pi(A) \setminus \{T_\varepsilon < \infty\} \right]P[π(A)∖{Tε​<∞}]﻿ of these two events can be made as small as desired.
To see that it is not always possible to choose a stopping time TTT﻿ that satisfies (S2)\text{(S2)}(S2)﻿ if A∈OA \in \mathscr{O}A∈O﻿, we will construct a filtration {Ft}t≥0\{\mathcal{F}_t\}_{t \ge 0}{Ft​}t≥0​﻿ and choose a set A∈OA \in \mathscr{O}A∈O﻿ that forces π(A)∖{T<∞}≠∅\pi(A) \setminus \{T < \infty\} \neq \varnothingπ(A)∖{T<∞}=∅﻿ for every stopping time TTT﻿ (the argument is from [3]).
To this end, let τ:Ω→(0,∞)\tau : \Omega \to (0, \infty)τ:Ω→(0,∞)﻿ be a random variable such that P{τ<t}>0\mathbb{P}\{\tau < t\} > 0P{τ<t}>0﻿ for all t>0.t > 0.t>0.﻿ For example, let τ\tauτ﻿ be such that its distribution is uniform on (0,1).(0,1).(0,1).﻿ Let {Ft}t≥0\{\mathcal{F}_t\}_{t \ge 0}{Ft​}t≥0​﻿ be the completed filtration such that Ft\mathcal{F}_tFt​﻿ is generated by {{τ≤s} : s≤t}\{\{\tau \le s\} \,:\, s \le t\}{{τ≤s}:s≤t}﻿, and thus τ\tauτ﻿ becomes a stopping time. Let A=⟧0,τ⟦ ,A = \rrbracket 0, \tau \llbracket\,,A=]]0,τ[[,﻿ which we know from Lemma 8 belongs to O.\mathscr{O}.O.﻿ Note that P{π(A)}=1\mathbb{P}\{\pi(A)\} = 1P{π(A)}=1﻿ by our construction.
It is easy to see that Ft\mathcal{F}_tFt​﻿ is trivial when restricted to {τ>t}\{\tau > t\}{τ>t}﻿, i.e., contains only sets of measure 000﻿ or 1.1.1.﻿ So, every Ft\mathcal{F}_tFt​﻿-measurable random variable is a.s. constant on the event {τ>t}.\{\tau > t\}.{τ>t}.﻿ Therefore, any stopping time TTT﻿ is deterministic on the event {T<τ}.\{T < \tau\}.{T<τ}.﻿ So, if ⟦T⟧⊆A\llbracket T \rrbracket \subseteq A[[T]]⊆A﻿, we have
T={son {τ>s}∞on {τ≤s}T = \begin{cases} s &\text{on } \{\tau > s\} \\ \infty &\text{on } \{\tau \le s\} \end{cases}T={s∞​on {τ>s}on {τ≤s}​
a.s. for some fixed s>0.s > 0.s>0.﻿ But then
P{T<∞}=P{τ>s}<1=P{π(A)}.\mathbb{P}\{T < \infty\} = \mathbb{P}\{\tau > s\} < 1 = \mathbb{P}\{\pi(A)\}.P{T<∞}=P{τ>s}<1=P{π(A)}.
A similar argument can be used to show that it is not possible to choose a predictable stopping time TTT﻿ that satisfies (S2)\text{(S2)}(S2)﻿ if A∈P.A \in \mathscr{P}.A∈P.﻿
Applications of Section Theorems
Recall the measurable graph theorem (Theorem 8 in part 1) which implies that a map T:Ω→[0,∞]T : \Omega \to [0, \infty]T:Ω→[0,∞]﻿ is measurable if and only if its graph ⟦T⟧\llbracket T \rrbracket[[T]]﻿ is measurable. We also have the following neat result:
Theorem 20: A random variable T:Ω→[0,∞]T : \Omega \to [0, \infty]T:Ω→[0,∞]﻿ is a stopping time (respectively, a predictable stopping time), if and only if its graph ⟦T⟧\llbracket T \rrbracket[[T]]﻿ is an optional (respectively, predictable) set.
Proof:
The necessity follows from the characterization of O\mathscr{O}O﻿ and P\mathscr{P}P﻿ in Lemma 8.
In the optional case, sufficiency follows from Theorem 14 and the fact that O⊆P⋆.\mathscr{O} \subseteq \mathscr{P}_\star.O⊆P⋆​.﻿
For the sufficiency in the predictable case, suppose ⟦T⟧\llbracket T \rrbracket[[T]]﻿ is predictable. Apply Predictable Section theorem (Theorem 18) for A=⟦T⟧A = \llbracket T \rrbracketA=[[T]]﻿ to construct a sequence {Tn}n∈N\{T_n\} _ {n \in \N}{Tn​}n∈N​﻿ of predictable stopping times such that
⟦Tn⟧⊆⟦T⟧ and P(T<∞)≤P(Tn<∞)+2−n,∀  n∈N.\llbracket T_n \rrbracket \subseteq \llbracket T \rrbracket \text{ and } \mathbb{P}(T < \infty) \le \mathbb{P}(T_n < \infty) + 2^{-n}, \quad \forall \; {n \in \N}.[[Tn​]]⊆[[T]] and P(T<∞)≤P(Tn​<∞)+2−n,∀n∈N.
Replacing TnT_nTn​﻿ by T1∨⋯∨TnT_1 \vee \cdots \vee T_nT1​∨⋯∨Tn​﻿ if necessary, we may assume that this sequence is increasing. It follows then that the limit
T=lim⁡n∈N↑Tn=sup⁡n∈NTnT = \lim _ {n \in \N} \uparrow T_n = \sup _ {n \in \N} T_nT=n∈Nlim​↑Tn​=n∈Nsup​Tn​
is predictable: if {Tnm}m∈N\{T_n^m\} _ {m \in \N}{Tnm​}m∈N​﻿ announces TnT_nTn​﻿, then
τn=max⁡{Tjk : j,k≤n}\tau_n = \max \{T_j^k \,: \, j,k \le n\}τn​=max{Tjk​:j,k≤n}
announces T.T.T.﻿ □\square□﻿
Suppose XXX﻿ and YYY﻿ are measurable processes such that
P{XT1{T<∞}=YT1{T<∞}}=1\mathbb{P}\left\{X_T \mathbf{1}_{\{T < \infty\}} = Y_T \mathbf{1}_{\{T < \infty\}}\right\} = 1P{XT​1{T<∞}​=YT​1{T<∞}​}=1
for each F\mathcal{F}F﻿-measurable T:Ω→[0,∞].T : \Omega \to [0, \infty].T:Ω→[0,∞].﻿ Then what can we say about XXX﻿ and Y?Y?Y?﻿ We will show that XXX﻿ and YYY﻿ are indistinguishable! To this end, let
F={(t,ω)∈[0,∞)×Ω : X(t,ω)≠Y(t,ω)}.F = \{(t,\omega) \in [0, \infty) \times \Omega \,:\, X(t,\omega) \neq Y(t, \omega)\}.F={(t,ω)∈[0,∞)×Ω:X(t,ω)=Y(t,ω)}.
It is measurable since XXX﻿ and YYY﻿ are measurable and due to our completeness assumption. We want to show that P{π(F)}=0\mathbb{P}\{\pi(F)\} = 0P{π(F)}=0﻿, so suppose to the contrary that P{π(F)}>0.\mathbb{P}\{\pi(F)\} > 0.P{π(F)}>0.﻿ Any F\mathcal{F}F﻿-measurable T:Ω→[0,∞]T : \Omega \to [0, \infty]T:Ω→[0,∞]﻿ satisfying ⟦T⟧⊆F\llbracket T \rrbracket \subseteq F[[T]]⊆F﻿ must also satisfy XT1{T<∞}≠YT1{T<∞}.X_T \mathbf{1}_{\{T < \infty\}} \neq Y_T \mathbf{1}_{\{T < \infty\}}.XT​1{T<∞}​=YT​1{T<∞}​.﻿ Now Measurable Section theorem (Theorem 10) says there exists a random variable T:Ω→[0,∞]T : \Omega \to [0,\infty]T:Ω→[0,∞]﻿ such that ⟦T⟧⊆F\llbracket T \rrbracket \subseteq F[[T]]⊆F﻿ and {T<∞}=π(F)\{T < \infty\} = \pi(F){T<∞}=π(F)﻿, and therefore
P{XT1{T<∞}≠YT1{T<∞}}≥P{T<∞}=P{π(F)}>0,\mathbb{P}\left\{X_T \mathbf{1}_{\{T < \infty\}} \neq Y_T \mathbf{1}_{\{T < \infty\}} \right\} \ge \mathbb{P}\{T < \infty\} = \mathbb{P}\{\pi(F)\} > 0,P{XT​1{T<∞}​=YT​1{T<∞}​}≥P{T<∞}=P{π(F)}>0,
contradicting our initial assumption.
Remarkably, we have similar results for optional and predictable processes.
Theorem 21: Suppose two optional (respectively, predictable) processes XXX﻿ and YYY﻿ agree at finite stopping times (respectively, predictable stopping times), i.e.,
P{XT1{T<∞}=YT1{T<∞}}=1,∀  T∈S  (respectively, T∈S(P)).\mathbb{P}\left\{X_T \mathbf{1}_{\{T < \infty\}} = Y_T \mathbf{1}_{\{T < \infty\}}\right\} = 1, \quad \forall \; T \in \mathfrak{S} \; \left(\text{respectively, } T \in \mathfrak{S}^{(\mathscr{P})}\right).P{XT​1{T<∞}​=YT​1{T<∞}​}=1,∀T∈S(respectively, T∈S(P)).
Then the two processes XXX﻿ and YYY﻿ are indistinguishable, i.e.,
P{Xt=Yt    ∀ t∈[0,∞)}=1.\mathbb{P}\{X_t = Y_t \;\; \forall \, t \in [0, \infty)\} = 1.P{Xt​=Yt​∀t∈[0,∞)}=1.
Proof:
Consider the optional case—the predictable case is similar. Just like above we have to show that for the optional set
F={(t,ω)∈[0,∞)×Ω : X(t,ω)≠Y(t,ω)},  P{π(F)}=0.F = \{(t,\omega) \in [0, \infty) \times \Omega \,:\, X(t,\omega) \neq Y(t, \omega)\}, \; \mathbb{P}\{\pi(F)\} = 0.F={(t,ω)∈[0,∞)×Ω:X(t,ω)=Y(t,ω)},P{π(F)}=0.
Suppose to the contrary that P{π(F)}=2ε>0\mathbb{P}\{\pi(F)\} = 2\varepsilon > 0P{π(F)}=2ε>0﻿ for some 0<ε≤1/2.0 < \varepsilon \le 1/2.0<ε≤1/2.﻿ Then the Optional Section theorem (Theorem 19) implies there exists a stopping time TεT_\varepsilonTε​﻿ with the properties
⟦Tε⟧⊆F and 2ε=P{π(F)}≤P{Tε<∞}+ε.\llbracket T_\varepsilon \rrbracket \subseteq F \text{ and } 2\varepsilon = \mathbb{P}\{\pi(F)\} \le \mathbb{P}\{T_\varepsilon < \infty\} + \varepsilon. [[Tε​]]⊆F and 2ε=P{π(F)}≤P{Tε​<∞}+ε.
But then
P{XTε1{Tε<∞}≠YTε1{Tε<∞}}≥P{Tε<∞}≥ε>0,\mathbb{P}\left\{X_{T_\varepsilon} \mathbf{1}_{\{T_\varepsilon < \infty\}} \neq Y_{T_\varepsilon} \mathbf{1}_{\{T_\varepsilon < \infty\}}\right\} \ge \mathbb{P}\{T_\varepsilon < \infty\} \ge \varepsilon > 0,P{XTε​​1{Tε​<∞}​=YTε​​1{Tε​<∞}​}≥P{Tε​<∞}≥ε>0,
contradicting our initial assumption. □\square□﻿
Projection Theorems
To motivate optional and predictable projections, let us start with a fundamental problem in filtering theory: Assume an underlying complete probability space (Ω,F,P).(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mathbb{P}).(Ω,F,P).﻿ There is an underlying signal X={Xt}t≥0X = \{X_t\} _ {t \ge 0}X={Xt​}t≥0​﻿ which is modelled as a stochastic process and which we are interested in studying. Our observation process has noise and therefore instead of observing XXX﻿ we observe a process Y={Yt}t≥0Y = \{Y_t\} _ {t \ge 0}Y={Yt​}t≥0​﻿ such that
Yt=ft(Xt,Wt),Y_t = f_t(X_t, W_t),Yt​=ft​(Xt​,Wt​),
for Brownian motion W={Wt}t≥0.W = \{W_t\}_{t \ge 0}.W={Wt​}t≥0​.﻿ Therefore, it makes sense to define F={Ft}t≥0\mathbb{F} = \{\mathcal{F}_t\} _ {t \ge 0}F={Ft​}t≥0​﻿ to be the minimal augemented filtration generated by Y.Y.Y.﻿ The problem, then, is to compute an estimate for XXX﻿ based on the observable data at time ttt﻿, viz. Ft.\mathcal{F}_t.Ft​.﻿
We could look at
Zt:=E(Xt∣Ft),(P1)Z_t := \mathbb{E} \left( X_t \mid \mathcal{F}_t \right), \tag{P1}Zt​:=E(Xt​∣Ft​),(P1)
as an estimate for XtX_tXt​﻿ at each time t≥0.t \ge 0.t≥0.﻿ The process Z={Zt}t≥0Z = \{Z_t\}_{t \ge 0}Z={Zt​}t≥0​﻿ is, of course, adapted. However, since conditional expectation is defined only up to P\mathbb{P}P﻿-a.s., what version of ZZZ﻿ should we choose? (P1)\text{(P1)}(P1)﻿ does not fix the paths of the process ZZZ﻿, which requires specifying its values at the uncountable set of time in [0,∞).[0, \infty).[0,∞).﻿ We would be very lucky if it were possible for us to choose a version of ZZZ﻿ such that (P1)\text{(P1)}(P1)﻿ holds not only for all t∈[0,∞)t \in [0, \infty)t∈[0,∞)﻿ but also for all finite stopping times. And indeed this is possible! This is part of the statement of the optional projection theorem.
On the other hand, if we want an estimate of XXX﻿ based on observable data before time ttt﻿, then our estimate would be
Zt=E(Xt∣Ft−)Z_t = \mathbb{E}(X_t \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-})Zt​=E(Xt​∣Ft−​)
where recall Ft−:=σ(⋃s<tFs).\mathcal{F}_{t-} := \sigma\left(\bigcup _ {s < t} \mathcal{F}_s\right).Ft−​:=σ(⋃s<t​Fs​).﻿ Again it is possible to choose a version of ZZZ﻿ such that this equality holds not only for all t∈[0,∞)t \in [0, \infty)t∈[0,∞)﻿ but also for all finite predictable stopping times, and this is part of the statement of the predictable projection theorem.
Theorem 22 [Optional and Predictable Projections]: Let XXX﻿ be a bounded, measurable (though not necessarily adapted) process.
There is a unique, modulo indistinguishability, optional process XoX^oXo﻿, called optional projection of XXX﻿, that satisfies for all stopping times T∈ST \in \mathfrak{S}T∈S﻿ the identity
E(XT1{T<∞}∣FT)=XTo1{T<∞}.(P2)\mathbb{E}\left( X_T \mathbf{1}_{\{T < \infty\}} \mid \mathcal{F}_T \right) = X^o_T \mathbf{1}_{\{T < \infty\}}. \tag{P2}E(XT​1{T<∞}​∣FT​)=XTo​1{T<∞}​.(P2)
There is a unique, modulo indistinguishability, predictable process XpX^pXp﻿, called predictable projection of XXX﻿, that satisfies for all predictable stopping times T∈S(P)T \in \mathfrak{S}^{(\mathscr{P})}T∈S(P)﻿ the identity
E(XT1{T<∞}∣FT−)=XTp1{T<∞}.(P3)\mathbb{E}\left( X_T \mathbf{1}_{\{T < \infty\}} \mid \mathcal{F}_{T-} \right) = X^p_T \mathbf{1}_{\{T < \infty\}}. \tag{P3}E(XT​1{T<∞}​∣FT−​)=XTp​1{T<∞}​.(P3)
Remarks:
Taking expectations in (P2)\text{(P2)}(P2)﻿ we get
E(XT1{T<∞})=E(XTo1{T<∞})(P4)\mathbb{E} \left(X_T \mathbf{1}_{\{T < \infty\}}\right) = \mathbb{E} \left(X_T^o \mathbf{1}_{\{T < \infty\}}\right) \tag{P4}E(XT​1{T<∞}​)=E(XTo​1{T<∞}​)(P4)
for all stopping times T∈S.T \in \mathfrak{S}.T∈S.﻿ Now suppose (P4)\text{(P4)}(P4)﻿ holds for all stopping times T∈S.T \in \mathfrak{S}.T∈S.﻿ Fix an arbitrary stopping time S∈SS \in \mathfrak{S}S∈S﻿ and a set A∈FSA \in \mathcal{F}_SA∈FS​﻿, and write (P4)\text{(P4)}(P4)﻿ for T=SAT = S_AT=SA​﻿ to get
E(XS1{S<∞}1A)=E(XSo1{S<∞}1A).\mathbb{E} \left(X_S \mathbf{1}_{\{S < \infty\}} \mathbf{1}_A\right) = \mathbb{E} \left(X_S^o \mathbf{1}_{\{S < \infty\}} \mathbf{1}_A\right).E(XS​1{S<∞}​1A​)=E(XSo​1{S<∞}​1A​).
But this immediately implies (P2)\text{(P2)}(P2)﻿ for stopping time S.S.S.﻿ Therefore, requiring (P2)\text{(P2)}(P2)﻿ to hold for all stopping times is equivalent to requiring (P4)\text{(P4)}(P4)﻿ to hold for for all stopping times.
Similarly, requiring (P3)\text{(P3)}(P3)﻿ to hold for all predictable stopping times is equivalent to requiring
E(XT1{T<∞})=E(XTp1{T<∞})(P5)\mathbb{E}\left( X_T \mathbf{1}_{\{T < \infty\}} \right) = \mathbb{E}\left(X^p_T \mathbf{1}_{\{T < \infty\}}\right) \tag{P5}E(XT​1{T<∞}​)=E(XTp​1{T<∞}​)(P5)
to hold for all predictable stopping times.
Operators o^oo﻿ and p^pp﻿ are linear operators, i.e., for bounded, measurable processes X,YX,YX,Y﻿ and a,b∈Ra,b \in \Ra,b∈R﻿,
(aX+bY)o=aXo+bYo, and(aX+bY)p=aXp+bYp,\begin{align*} (aX + bY)^o &= a X^o + bY^o, \text{ and} \\ (aX + bY)^p &= a X^p + bY^p, \end{align*}(aX+bY)o(aX+bY)p​=aXo+bYo, and=aXp+bYp,​
as can be easily verified by using the properties of conditional expectation. The formulation of (P4)\text{(P4)}(P4)﻿ and (P5)\text{(P5)}(P5)﻿ makes it obvious that (Xo)o=Xo\left(X^o\right)^o = X^o(Xo)o=Xo﻿ and (Xp)p=Xp.\left(X^p\right)^p = X^p.(Xp)p=Xp.﻿ This explains the terminology of "projection".
Proof of Theorem 22:
Uniqueness is immediate from Theorem 21, so let's focus on existence, first for optional projection and then for predictable projection.
We will employ the monotone class theorem for functions. We need a simple class of processes for which finding an optional projection is easy to summon. To this end, consider the processes of the form
Xt(ω)=1B(ω)1[u,v)(t),0≤u<v<∞ and B∈F.X_t(\omega) = \mathbf{1}_{B}(\omega) \mathbf{1}_{[u,v)}(t), \quad 0 \le u < v < \infty \text{ and } B \in \mathcal{F}. Xt​(ω)=1B​(ω)1[u,v)​(t),0≤u<v<∞ and B∈F.
We claim that the candidate for the optional projection is
Xto(ω):=Mt(ω)1[u,v)(t),X^o_t(\omega) := M_t(\omega) \mathbf{1}_{[u,v)}(t),Xto​(ω):=Mt​(ω)1[u,v)​(t),
where MMM﻿ is the right-continuous version of the bounded, thus also uniformly integrable, martingale E(1B∣Ft)\mathbb{E}\left( \mathbf{1}_B \mid \mathcal{F}_t \right)E(1B​∣Ft​)﻿ (see [1,2] for the proof of existence of such a martingale; it is here that the usual conditions on the filtration F\mathbb{F}F﻿ become crucial).
With these choices and an arbitrary stopping time TTT﻿, the left-hand side of (P4)\text{(P4)}(P4)﻿ becomes P{B∩{u≤T<v}}\mathbb{P}\{B \cap \{u \le T < v\}\}P{B∩{u≤T<v}}﻿, whereas optional stopping theorem [1,2] shows that its right-hand side is
E(E(1B∣FT)∣1[u,v)(T)).\mathbb{E} \left( \mathbb{E} \left(\mathbf{1}_B \mid \mathcal{F}_T \right) \mid \mathbf{1}_{[u,v)}(T) \right).E(E(1B​∣FT​)∣1[u,v)​(T)).
Recalling now that TTT﻿ is FT\mathcal{F}_TFT​﻿-measurable shows that the two sides are equal.
Finally, use linearity and monotone class arguments to establish existence for arbitrary bounded, measurable X.X.X.﻿
Similar ideas work in the predictable case. We first consider processes of the form
Xt(ω)=1B(ω)1(u,v](t),0≤u<v<∞ and B∈F.X_t(\omega) = \mathbf{1}_{B}(\omega) \mathbf{1}_{(u,v]}(t), \quad 0 \le u < v < \infty \text{ and } B \in \mathcal{F}. Xt​(ω)=1B​(ω)1(u,v]​(t),0≤u<v<∞ and B∈F.
We claim that the candidate for the predictable projection is
Xtp(ω):=Mt−(ω)1(u,v](t),X^p_t(\omega) := M_{t-}(\omega) \mathbf{1}_{(u,v]}(t),Xtp​(ω):=Mt−​(ω)1(u,v]​(t),
where Mt−M_{t-}Mt−​﻿ is the left-continuous version of the martingale MMM﻿ defined previously. Again using FT−\mathcal{F}_{T-}FT−​﻿-measurability of TTT﻿ we see the two sides of (P5)\text{(P5)}(P5)﻿ are equal. Monotone class arguments now allow us to finish the proof. □\square□﻿
We end our discussion with a result on time change. We call it a “time change” because given an adapted increasing process AAA﻿ with right-continuous paths and A0=0,A_0 = 0,A0​=0,﻿ we imagine a clock which runs according to AAA﻿ in the sense that at time ttt﻿ this clock shows time At.A_t.At​.﻿
Theorem 23: Suppose AAA﻿ is an adapted increasing process with right-continuous paths and A0=0.A_0 = 0.A0​=0.﻿
For any two bounded, measurable processes XXX﻿ and YYY﻿ that satisfy
E(XT1{T<∞})=E(YT1{T<∞}),∀  T∈S,(T1)\mathbb{E} \left(X_T \mathbf{1}_{\{T < \infty\}}\right) = \mathbb{E} \left(Y_T \mathbf{1}_{\{T < \infty\}}\right), \quad \forall \; T \in \mathfrak{S}, \tag{T1}E(XT​1{T<∞}​)=E(YT​1{T<∞}​),∀T∈S,(T1)
we have
E∫0TXt dAt=E∫0TYt dAt,∀  T∈S.(T2)\mathbb{E} \int_0^T X_t \,\mathrm{d}A_t = \mathbb{E} \int_0^T Y_t \,\mathrm{d}A_t, \quad \forall \; T \in \mathfrak{S}. \tag{T2}E∫0T​Xt​dAt​=E∫0T​Yt​dAt​,∀T∈S.(T2)
For any non-negative, RCLL and uniformly integrable martingale M,M,M,﻿ we have
E∫0TMt dAt=E(MTAT),∀  T∈S.\mathbb{E} \int_0^T M_t \,\mathrm{d}A_t = \mathbb{E} \left( M_T A_T\right), \quad \forall \; T \in \mathfrak{S}.E∫0T​Mt​dAt​=E(MT​AT​),∀T∈S.
Proof:
Introduce the time change
C(s):=inf⁡{t≥0 : At>s},C(s) := \inf \{t \ge 0 \,:\, A_t > s\},C(s):=inf{t≥0:At​>s},
and check that C(s)C(s)C(s)﻿ is a stopping time for each s≥0.s \ge 0.s≥0.﻿ Recall that C(s)C(s)C(s)﻿ is increasing, right-continuous, and the “functional inverse” of AtA_tAt​﻿ in the sense that
At=inf⁡{s≥0 : C(s)>t}.A_t = \inf \{s \ge0 \,:\, C(s) > t\}.At​=inf{s≥0:C(s)>t}.
Therefore, CCC﻿ gives us a way to read the correct time off our AAA﻿-clock—if the AAA﻿-clock shows time s,s,s,﻿ the actual time is C(s).C(s).C(s).﻿
We also check that the properties
∫0∞g(At) dAt=∫0A(∞)g(u) du, and ∫0∞g(t) dAt=∫0A(∞)g(C(s)) ds=∫0∞g(C(s))1{C(s)<∞} ds\begin{gather*} \int_0^\infty g(A_t) \, \mathrm{d}A_t = \int_0^{A(\infty)} g(u) \, \mathrm{d}u, \text{ and } \\ \int_0^\infty g(t) \, \mathrm{d}A_t = \int_0^{A(\infty)} g(C(s)) \, \mathrm{d}s = \int_0^\infty g(C(s)) \mathbf{1}_{\{C(s) < \infty\}}\, \mathrm{d}s \end{gather*}∫0∞​g(At​)dAt​=∫0A(∞)​g(u)du, and ∫0∞​g(t)dAt​=∫0A(∞)​g(C(s))ds=∫0∞​g(C(s))1{C(s)<∞}​ds​
hold for any Borel-measurable g ⁣:[0,∞)→[0,∞).g \colon [0, \infty) \to [0, \infty).g:[0,∞)→[0,∞).﻿ It follows from these considerations and Fubini’s theorem, that
E∫0TXt dAt=E∫0TX(C(s))1{C(s)<∞} ds=∫0∞E[X(C(s))1{C(s)<∞}] ds\mathbb{E} \int_0^T X_t \,\mathrm{d}A_t = \mathbb{E} \int_0^T X(C(s)) \mathbf{1}_{\{C(s) < \infty\}}\, \mathrm{d}s = \int_0^\infty \mathbb{E}\left[X(C(s)) \mathbf{1}_{\{C(s) < \infty\}} \right] \, \mathrm{d}sE∫0T​Xt​dAt​=E∫0T​X(C(s))1{C(s)<∞}​ds=∫0∞​E[X(C(s))1{C(s)<∞}​]ds
holds, with a similar expression also holding for Y.Y.Y.﻿
The claim (T2)\text{(T2)}(T2)﻿ now follows directly from our assumptions, in the case T=∞.T = \infty.T=∞.﻿ For general T∈ST \in \mathfrak ST∈S﻿ we apply the above result to the increasing, right-continuous and adapted process
A~t:=At1⟦0,T⟦(t)+AT1⟦T,∞⟦(t),t≥0.\tilde{A}_t := A_t \mathbf{1}_{\llbracket 0, T\llbracket}(t) + A_T \mathbf{1}_{\llbracket T, \infty \llbracket}(t), \quad t \ge 0.A~t​:=At​1[[0,T[[​(t)+AT​1[[T,∞[[​(t),t≥0.
This follows immediately from part-1 by letting
X:=M1⟦0,T⟧ and Y:=MT1⟦0,T⟧,X := M \mathbf{1}_{\llbracket 0, T \rrbracket} \text{ and } Y := M_T \mathbf{1}_{\llbracket 0, T \rrbracket},X:=M1[[0,T]]​ and Y:=MT​1[[0,T]]​,
and using Doob’s optional sampling theorem [1,2] to verify that these processes satisfy (T1).\text{(T1)}.(T1).﻿ □\square□﻿
